channel.title: 2 Computer set-ups
channel.description:
Hello,
you might have seen my thread before where i wanted to buy a new CPU for my current pc, long story short.. i decided to get a new pc because i can't take it anymore with this old one.. , So i got two set-ups i made from a local store website for pc's below. All i need help with is the following:
- Is it good for it's price? - Is there anything that can be modified? ( like a better and cheaper part - if available ) - Is it a good set-up overall for modest/medium gaming, work, etc.
I'd really appreciate your help, anyway, the set ups are:
[u][b]Set up #1:[/b][/u]
[spoiler]
PcPartPicker Link: [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/p/XXJMD3]http://pcpartpicker.com/p/XXJMD3[/url]
[u][b]Prices at the store:[/b][/u]
[b]Processor:[/b] Intel Pentium G3250 3.2GHz Dual-Core - $79.58
[b]Video Card:[/b] Sapphire Radeon R7 260X 2GB - $149.05
[b]Motherboard:[/b] Gigabyte GA-H81M-S2PV Micro ATX LGA1150 - $72.00
[b]Memory:[/b] Transcend 4GB (1 x 4GB) DDR3-1333 - $53.05
[b]Hard Drive:[/b] Western Digital Caviar Blue 500GB 3.5" 7200RPM - $68.21
[b]Optical Writer:[/b] Asus DRW-24D3ST DVD±RW x24 Black Sata - $30.31
[b]Power Supply:[/b] Antec 450W ATX Power Supply - $53.05
[b]Case:[/b] Antec One S3 Mid Tower Gaming Black Case No PSU - $48.00 - [b]Wasn't available at PcPartPicker added case with same price[/b]
_______________
[b]TOTAL:[/b] [b]$505.25[/b]
[b]TOTAL at PcPartPicker[/b] [b]$412.13[/b] [/spoiler]
[u][b]Set up #2:[/b][/u]
[spoiler]
PcPartPicker Link: [url=http://pcpartpicker.com/p/shv3Bm]http://pcpartpicker.com/p/shv3Bm[/url]
[u][b]Prices at the store:[/b][/u]
[b]Processor:[/b] AMD A6-7400K 3.5GHz Dual-Core - $83.36
[b]Video Card:[/b] Sapphire Radeon R7 260X 2GB - $149.05
[b]Motherboard:[/b] Gigabyte GA-F2A88XM-HD3 Micro ATX FM2+ - $74.52
[b]Memory:[/b] Transcend 4GB (1 x 4GB) DDR3-1333 - $53.05
[b]Hard Drive:[/b] Western Digital Caviar Blue 500GB 3.5" 7200RPM - $68.21
[b]Optical Writer:[/b] Asus DRW-24D3ST DVD±RW x24 Black Sata - $30.31
[b]Power Supply:[/b] Antec 450W ATX Power Supply - $64.42
[b]Case:[/b] Antec One S3 Mid Tower Gaming Black Case No PSU - $48.00 - [b]Wasn't available at PcPartPicker added case with same price[/b]
_______________
[b]TOTAL:[/b] [b]$570.92[/b]
[b]TOTAL at PcPartPicker[/b] [b]$418.21[/b] [/spoiler]
i'm also thinking of ordering every piece online.. look at the prices!! wtf.
edit: my budget is around $500+- , so if there are any better parts but cost more i will try to add more to the budget. but lower price is better

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

Rix_:

I’d choose 1x4GB RAM stick over 2x2GB and drop the CPU cooler to get the GTX 750Ti for a few more bucks.

I actually updated both those parts and a new case: just forgot to edit the thread

VGA: http://www.msi.com/product/vga/N750Ti-TF-2GD5OC.html#hero-overview
RAM: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820104441
CASE: http://us.coolermaster.com/product/Detail/case/mid-tower/haf-912.html

I am going to order the parts this sunday, so any suggestions are welcome until so.

And i rather keep the CPU cooler no matter what, the hot summer weather here is horrible

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

I’d choose 1x4GB RAM stick over 2x2GB and drop the CPU cooler to get the GTX 750Ti for a few more bucks.

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

Had to delete my last post to post again.
But anyway, Let’s get down to it…

I postponed my order or rather cancel it, Since i had to save up more money in the last few weeks for some PC accessories, mouse , keyboard , cables , speakers , monitor because i’m giving my old PC to my brother so i’ll just give away everything with it, and ended up with around 700$-+ budget to be exact.

Now i’v been circling around a lot of choices even though i said i had one in mind at last but there was always something bugging me with the review people wrote about the products that i have been choosing making me question what to choose and try to keep it top quality yet cheap. So now i got this after a long research:

CPU: Intel Pentium G3258 3.2GHz
CPU Cooler: Arctic Freezer 11 LP
Motherboard: Asus H81M-PLUS
RAM: G.Skill 2x2GB DDR3 1333Mhz NQ Editiona dual channel
VGA: MSI GTX 750 2GB Twin Frozr EDIT
Storage: Western Digital Caviar Blue WD10EZEX 1TB Sata III
PSU: Corsair CX500M
Case: Corsair Carbide 200R

PcPartPicker link: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/GhPBWZ ( Price is not accurate at all there )

Okay now here is the trick, now that i decided not to order any part online, everything will be purchased from a local store. Here is how you can see what parts i can buy at http://en.ksp.co.il/… ( should be English already ) , Price will be listed in “shekels” as you can see. You simply click on the part and choose from a long list of parts, available ones will be ticked.

The goal is not to exceed 1700 “shekels” ( W/O CPU & VGA ), and do not choose a CPU or a VGA from that store as i will buy those from another one since the G3258 isn’t available here neither is the MSI GTX750, if you are interested in exploring that other website it is: www.ivory.co.il ( sorry no English there , just use chrome or firefox to translate ).

So are my choices wise from a side of quality and price? If anything that can be changed please tell me, I will be very grateful.

Thank you!

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:24, topic:549149”]I got into a bump while buying the video card, i don’t know wherether to choose a sapphire r7 260x 2gb or a gigabyte GT740 2gb, since i read that people complained about the R7 having driver issues…

and also there is a third option which costs one more buck, the gigabyte GTX750 OC 1gb.

I’d appreciate your thoughts, thank you.[/quote]

Get the R7 260X for sure.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“PaulT, post:27, topic:549149”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=668057.msg4470918#msg4470918 date=1422864867]
Instead of pissing around with overclocking, why don’t you just keep the stock cooler (and the other motherboard you wanted) and use the money you save to buy a better CPU?
[/quote]

You would need a $300 GPU to realistically bottleneck a G3258. Unless you are playing a lot of CPU intensive games like Rome:TW or things of that nature, a nice OC’ed dual core should work fine.[/quote]

I really won’t be playing those high end games, So that’s why the G3258 should be more than enough with either video cards

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

SilentCJ:

Instead of pissing around with overclocking, why don’t you just keep the stock cooler (and the other motherboard you wanted) and use the money you save to buy a better CPU?

You would need a $300 GPU to realistically bottleneck a G3258. Unless you are playing a lot of CPU intensive games like Rome:TW or things of that nature, a nice OC’ed dual core should work fine.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

SilentCJ:

Instead of pissing around with overclocking, why don’t you just keep the stock cooler (and the other motherboard you wanted) and use the money you save to buy a better CPU?

the diffrence was really cheap so i went on with the pentium, and a better CPU would equal the cost to be the same as before expect cheaper mobo and no cooler. I will think about this, meanwhile, what about the VGA?

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“Rix_, post:23, topic:549149”]Hmm looks like you can’t overclock the G3258 on that mobo. Other than that, your build looks fine although I’ve never heard about Corsair VS PSUs.

Your motherboard will have an ethernet port so it already acts as a net device. If you want wi-fi you can buy a USB adapter.[/quote]

Well there is the Asus H81M-K , costs a little more but it supports OC’ing that CPU. Also changed the PSU to another more reliable one that just costs just one more buck , because i have a dark past with my old PC’s psu. Also thank you for pointing that out

CPU: Intel Pentium G3258 3.2GHz Dual-Core $82.78

CPU Cooler: Arctic Cooling ACFZ13 $34.39

Motherboard: Asus H81M-K $76.41
Motherboard: Asus H81M-PLUS $92.67

Memory: G.Skill AEGIS 4GB (1 x 4GB) DDR3-1600 $50.94

VideoCard: Sapphire Radeon R7 260X 2GB $150.28

Hard disk: Western Digital Caviar Blue 500GB AAKX $68.77

PSU: Corsair 450W (VS450) $63.68
PSU: Corsair 430W (CX430) $64.74

Case: Thermaltake V3 VL80001W2Z $40.75

For a total of: $568 $585.32

…damn i thought building a pc would be straight forward… i guess i was wrong.

SECOND EDIT:

sorry for the bump, but urgent question.

I got into a bump while buying the video card, i don’t know wherether to choose a sapphire r7 260x 2gb or a gigabyte GT740 2gb, since i read that people complained about the R7 having driver issues…

and also there is a third option which costs one more buck, the gigabyte GTX750 OC 1gb.

I’d appreciate your thoughts, thank you.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Hmm looks like you can’t overclock the G3258 on that mobo. Other than that, your build looks fine although I’ve never heard about Corsair VS PSUs.

Your motherboard will have an ethernet port so it already acts as a net device. If you want wi-fi you can buy a USB adapter.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

Rix_:

So what does the part list look like now OP? If you’re not overclocking you can save a few bucks by sticking with the stock CPU cooler.

Okay here is the final conclusion and equal between performance and budget: ( and yes i am overclocking, that’s why i got a nice CPU cooler )

CPU: Intel Pentium G3258 3.2GHz Dual-Core $82.78

CPU Cooler: Arctic Cooling ACFZ13 $34.39

Motherboard: Asus H81M-K $76.41

Memory: G.Skill AEGIS 4GB (1 x 4GB) DDR3-1600 $50.94

VideoCard: Sapphire Radeon R7 260X 2GB $150.28

Hard disk: Western Digital Caviar Blue 500GB AAKX $68.77

PSU: Corsair 450W (VS450) $63.68

Case: Thermaltake V3 VL80001W2Z $40.75

For a total of: $568 ( Prices are according to my country, so some parts might cost more )

Pretty good i’d say so myself.

Edit: One last question though! what about a net device? dont i need that to connect to the internet through cable connection?

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

So what does the part list look like now OP? If you’re not overclocking you can save a few bucks by sticking with the stock CPU cooler.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:17, topic:549149”]Just one question… might sound dumb , but if i buy the CPU right now and put it on shelf til i get the rest of the parts, will it wear out somehow or something? I don’t know just worried a bit[/quote]Don’t hold out too long though. There is always the possibility that you may not find a mobo that supports it.

Read full topic

It will be fine. Just don’t spill coffee on it.

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

My Win8.1 boots in 8 seconds on a 7200RPM HDD…Sure it would be nice to have an SSD to help game load times and desktop responsiveness! But is it worth spending $100 right now? Not for me. With 6-Cores running at 4.4GHz ($80 for an FX-6300) and a motherboard that boots up in eight seconds (AsRock 970 Extreme 3, $50) and RAM running at 2133Mhz, it’s very fast, and I can always drop the SSD in later. Build a good foundation first, an SSD is an “Extra” in my opinion.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JdOAvlncCOw

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:14, topic:549149”][quote author=naseem142 link=topic=668057.msg4468505#msg4468505 date=1421580378]

Agreed with the no DVD drive, I use a single external USB drive (in the rare occasion I actually need to use a DVD/CD) that cost me £10 for all my computers and it does everything I need.

Have you thought about getting an SSD? Can pick one up stupidly cheap now and it’s one of the best performance upgrades you can get particularly for the price. Even if you just get a 60gb one that’d be fine, though I’d advise 120gb and above.

This is a good price at the moment for example and is a reliable product: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820171646

but an ssd has less storage and more expensive.
[/quote]
No the idea is that you have both an SSD and a hard drive, you install the operating system (and programs) on the SSD and store your libraries (documents, music, pictures, videos etc) on your HDD. This speeds up your entire system. Boot up times and program opening times are on average minimised by at least three times.

This video is cheesy and on a Mac but you get the idea:

[youtube]ma954EkQkeM[/youtube]

Plenty more comparisons out there, once you have one you won’t go back.

My Windows 8 system boots up in around 8 seconds, and large programs like Photoshop, 3ds Max etc are all less than 5 seconds, also always one of the first players in games like Battlefield and that.[/quote]

that’s pretty neat indeed :o

I will try to squeeze an SSD into my budget. thank you

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:13, topic:549149”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=668057.msg4468497#msg4468497 date=1421572099]
Agreed with the no DVD drive, I use a single external USB drive (in the rare occasion I actually need to use a DVD/CD) that cost me £10 for all my computers and it does everything I need.

Have you thought about getting an SSD? Can pick one up stupidly cheap now and it’s one of the best performance upgrades you can get particularly for the price. Even if you just get a 60gb one that’d be fine, though I’d advise 120gb and above.

This is a good price at the moment for example and is a reliable product: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820171646
[/quote]

but an ssd has less storage and more expensive. [/quote]
No the idea is that you have both an SSD and a hard drive, you install the operating system (and programs) on the SSD and store your libraries (documents, music, pictures, videos etc) on your HDD. This speeds up your entire system. Boot up times and program opening times are on average minimised by at least three times.

This video is cheesy and on a Mac but you get the idea:

[youtube]ma954EkQkeM[/youtube]

Plenty more comparisons out there, once you have one you won’t go back.

My Windows 8 system boots up in around 8 seconds, and large programs like Photoshop, 3ds Max etc are all less than 5 seconds, also always one of the first players in games like Battlefield and that.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“PaulT, post:9, topic:549149”]Yeah those Arctic Freezer units look good actually, nice heat pipes.

If you can’t buy online, well, that severely limits your options. R7 should be fine for your build, and Sapphire is the best OEM for Radeon Cards most of the time (apart from Asus), but $190.11 is still pretty steep. Consider that (US Retail price) an R9 270 is $175 and performs 1000 points better in futuremark.[/quote]

well that’s a bummer …

But i found this to be interesting!

It is described as used but still in a perfect condition, and whats even better that it isn’t from usa so that’s good.

Read full topic

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Yeah those Arctic Freezer units look good actually, nice heat pipes.

If you can’t buy online, well, that severely limits your options. R7 should be fine for your build, and Sapphire is the best OEM for Radeon Cards most of the time (apart from Asus), but $190.11 is still pretty steep. Consider that (US Retail price) an R9 270 is $175 and performs 1000 points better in futuremark.

item.title: 2 Computer set-ups
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“PaulT, post:7, topic:549149”]Intel stock coolers are actually pretty good, so it looks like that Alpine 11 is only incrementally better, but since you’re going to be running that G3258 OC’ed, its’ probably worth it to spend a little more on cooling. You can get a better cooler for literally just a couple bucks:
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B0028Y4S9K

http://us.coolermaster.com/product/Lines/hyper-series.html

As far as the graphics card goes, you’re probably good with an R7 if you’re cool with using medium settings. Especially if you don’t have a 1080p monitor. If you want to get good framerates at 1080p I would highly suggest poking around for a discounted R9.[/quote]

The coolermaster model you mentioned is ridiculously overpriced at a $53.00 like wtf. And im sure if i try to import it from ebay they’d tax it up to that value…

But i found similiar coolers that might do the job as good:

Arctic Freezer 7 PRO Rev.2 - $30.43

Arctic Freezer 13 $34.24

Arctic Freezer 13 CO $35.51

And for the gpu, since i’m getting something beefy i might aswell spend it on something worth it. So i got in mind the Sapphire radeon R7 265 Dual-X 2gb for a $190.11

Read full topic
